Award.AwardTitle: SEES Fellow: Linking Rural Smallholder Soil and Water Management Practices in Tropical Deltas to Sea Level Rise Vulnerability

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project is supported under the NSF Science, Engineering and Education for Sustainability Fellows (SEES Fellows) program, with the goal of helping to enable discoveries needed to inform actions that lead to environmental, energy and societal sustainability while creating the necessary workforce to address these challenges. Sustainability science is an emerging field that addresses the challenges of meeting human needs without harm to the environment, and without sacrificing the ability of future generations to meet their needs. A strong scientific workforce requires individuals educated and trained in interdisciplinary research and thinking, especially in the area of sustainability science. With SEES Fellowship support, this project will enable a promising early career researcher to establish herself in an independent research career related to sustainability. This interdisciplinary (geosciences and social sciences) project will explore linkages between smallholder soil and water management practices in tropical deltas to sea level rise vulnerability.

The fertile soils, vibrant ecosystems and abundant waterways of tropical deltas have attracted humans and supported social, cultural and economic development for millennia. Unfortunately, their high populations and cultivated, flat landscapes also make tropical deltas vulnerable to sea level rise predicted in this century. To address coupled socio-biophysical feedbacks between smallholder farm practices and regional scale vulnerability to coastal flooding in tropical deltas, this study will utilize two complementary conceptual frameworks to identify links between rural soil and water management practices and erosion and increased tidal flooding for development of a geospatial analysis and open-source coupled model. The study focuses on the Ganges-Brahmaputra delta in Bangladesh, where social and environmental concerns converge, thus providing a dynamic, complex and globally significant case study for understanding coupled biophysical and socioeconomic processes. The research will advance understanding of how these coupled processes underlie the sustainability of human-natural delta systems by applying an Institutional Development and Analysis Framework, and a SocioEcological Systems Framework. The analyses and results will be produced and stored in open-source formats that will provide for broad dissemination of the results to policy makers, environmental managers, development organizations, and foreign agricultural extensions. The SEES Fellow, Dr. Kimberly Rogers, will work with host mentor Dr. James Syvitski at the University of Colorado, and with partner mentor Dr. Eduardo Brondizio at Indiana University Bloomington.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Occupying just 5% of global land area, tropical river deltas house over 7% of the world’s population, including rapidly developing, densely populated Asian megacities. From a biophysical point of view, 20th century societies changed the nature of how deltas function. Dams and reservoirs constructed to provide communities in river basins with water for irrigation and energy have reduced net downstream sediment discharge to the coastal ocean by 15%. On the downstream end, embankments designed to reduce the risk of devastating river floods alter the sediment balance on deltaic surfaces. Static dikes restrict channel migration that naturally replenishes carbon-rich soil needed to sustain crop productivity and maintain surface elevation. As river basin and deltaic populations grow, development-related infrastructure building will continue to affect the movement of sediment and water on deltas, just as climate change-related coastal flooding becomes more commonplace. 

This research focused on understanding interactions between river and coastal proceses, and local-scale governance of an state-built infrastructure system within a densely populated tropical river delta. Specifically, the study made use of a nested conceptual framework to guide the research design and execution of (i) field campaigns to collect socio-demographic and perceptions data in two districts of a heavily farmed river delta with an expansive flood control embankment system; (ii) a geospatial analysis to examine the influence of multi-scale biophysical, engineering, and institutional structures in the two study areas, and (iii) an open-source agent-based model to examine how local-scale infrastructure governance impacts overall socio-technical-ecological system fitness and vulnerability to coastal flooding. A few results from the project are highlighted here.  

Complex interactions between multiple levels of institutions, infrastructure, and physical processes were examined using a nested conceptual framework. The framework linked decision making related to infrastructure governance at the geopolitical/river basin scale to feedbacks at the local/arable land patch scale within the delta. For example, water diversion in river basins reduces dry season water availability and overall sediment delivery to the delta, thus amplifying local drought effects and fertilizer application by individual farmers. Local level interactions move upstream, as well. Interactions between individuals and flood-control infrastructure impact higher jurisdictional levels by inducing market fluctuations that stem from the embankment system’s efficacy in protecting cropland from coastal flooding.  

However, infrastructure governance at the local scale was found to be spatially variable within both study areas. Adjacent communities use different rules for determining whether they will take the initiative to repair a failing embankment. Some communities believe that it is the responsibility of the state government to repair a failing embankment and thus do not participate in embankment maintenance, while a neighboring community will take the initiative to informally repair a failure. Personal risk perceptions and tolerance, trust in the government to subsidize repair costs, and social connectivity are major predictors of whether an individual will participate in a community effort to repair a local failure to an embankment. A subject's risk tolerance, which is partly a function of memory of a past flood event and where their land is relative to the embankment, impacts the response time it takes for them to decide whether to participate in a collective repair effort. 

From a theoretical standpoint, these results suggest that the collective informal governance of infrastructure may lead to overall decline in the infrastructure system’s robustness, rather than support the system’s fitness, as is observed in other flood control systems governed by a polycentric structure. Practically speaking, these results demonstrate the importance of place-based interactions between physical processes, the built environment, and institutional structures and their collective impact on overall coastal resilience. The findings of this research project have implications for development and adaptation policy in developing countries situated in tropical deltas. More broadly, these results can be used to inform coastal adaptation measures applied to densely populated coastal settings in the United States where infrastructure is also being used to combat the effects of flooding from sea level rise.
